Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Clarifying comments: An article is a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity and (in)definiteness. Sometimes these notions of specificity and definiteness are summed up in the term "identifiability".  A language does not necessarily have both a non-specific/indefinite and a specific/definite marker. These markers often stem from very different sources (numerals and demonstratives) and need not to be similar in formal expression or position.  The formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone. Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm where there are markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum making it hard to define discrete categories. Articles are more grammaticalized, i.e. are often obligatory in certain contexts that require definite or specific reference. Definite or specific articles can also grammaticalize from pronouns meaning 'a certain'. As articles necessarily accompany nouns, it is in these cases that it is necessary to investigate whether the marker can occur independently or not; if it can it is most likely a pronoun and not an article. Articles can be homophonous with pronouns and demonstratives, and also with classifiers.

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Clarifying comments: In this question, we need explicit support that indefinite NPs do/do not commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Indefinite articles can be homophonous with demonstratives, the numeral 'one' or classifiers.

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order.  'Articles' refers to definite or indefinite articles as defined in GB020 and GB021 respectively. In order to answer 1 for this feature, the marker's functions need to meet one of those definitions, and so 1 should also have been answered for GB020 or GB021.
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, prefixation

Feature: Are there postnominal articles?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning the order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. 'Articles' refers to definite or indefinite articles as defined in GB020 and GB021 respectively. In order to answer 1 for this feature, the marker's functions need to meet one of those definitions, and so 1 should also have been answered for GB020 or GB021.
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, suffixation

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Clarifying comments: Consider cardinal numerals only (i.e., not ordinal numerals). It does not matter what kind of construction is required (e.g., attributive 'two books' or relative 'books that are two') or what word class the root or modifying form of that the cardinal numerals belong to, i.e., 'two-ing books' (verb) or 'two-some books' (noun) apply to this question. If some numerals go before the noun and some go after, code 3 (both orders). If there is a free choice where to place the numeral, code 3 (both orders) as well. If the order depends on some other grammatical category which is neutral with respect to pragmaticality (e.g. definiteness), code 3. If the order depends on the noun consider the order(s) that applies to an open class of nouns.

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature is concerned with the order of the noun and the adnominal (classes of words which modify the noun) demonstrative. There are three possible values to code, before the noun, after the noun, or that both orders are possible. Like all questions concerning the order of elements, only the pragmatically unmarked orders are targeted.

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Clarifying comments: This means that a restrictively interpreted adjective is separated from the noun by some element that is not part of the nominal. For example, can you say "The man is running big" and the like to mean "The big man is running". Typically a language which allows this has extensive agreement systems so that you can still work out what modifies what in the NP without them being adjacent (i.e. the "Australian type"). NPs that are made up of several coordinated NPs that can be interpreted by the verb or other elements are not relevant here. This features aims to capture NPs where the head and modifiers can be separated. Examples of the type "I painted the house red" or "I saw the boy big" are not necessarily discontinuous, but most likely resultative or contrastive ("I saw the boy big [as opposed to before when he was small]").

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Clarifying comments: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John with Mary went to market')? This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this (to a certain extent). In some languages the only way to do nominal coordination is with a comitative phrase, i.e., the only way to say X and Y is to say X with Y. This feature aims to capture such languages (which, as they have no difference between coordination and comitatives for nouns, get a 0). To see whether an element is comitative or coordinating check for case marking, agreement etc. For example, if X is the element in question and in the dative you get 'John-DAT X Mary-DAT' then X is likely coordinating, while if you get John-DAT X Mary then X is likely comitative. Or with agreement, if you get 'John X Mary verb-PL' rather than 'John X Mary verb-SG' (just like 'John X suitcase verb-SG') then that suggests X is likely coordinating.
Function: argument marking, oblique, conjunction, coordination, case marking, comitative

Feature: Is there a distinction between inclusive and exclusive?
Clarifying comments: Is there a pronoun or other marker that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor? This feature is not restricted to the pronominal system but includes person indexing as well. If inclusive is marked overtly in either the pronominal system or through verbal marking this is sufficient to trigger a (1) for this feature, even if exclusive has no overt morphological marking.

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This question targets the existence of a gender distinction in independent 3rd person anaphoric forms, which includes pronouns and also demonstratives. This distinction is often one of natural gender (masc./fem), but it could be animacy as well (see Corbett 1991 for further discussion of gender). For languages with no 3rd person independent pronouns a gender distinction in demonstratives would trigger a (1) here. If pronouns with inanimate referents agree with the gender/noun class of that inanimate noun that will also suffice for (1) here. If a language has a gender distinction for 3rd person pronouns but not for demonstratives, this is also sufficient for a (1) in this category.

Feature: Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Clarifying comments: A dual or unit augmented form must be present throughout the paradigm (i.e. for all person categories) for this feature to be coded as 1. Both bound and free person forms are to be considered in coding this feature. Inclusive and exclusive categories of 1st person are not considered separate person categories for the purposes of coding this feature (e.g. if a language has dual number in 3rd, 2nd, and any 1st person category it is sufficient for triggering a 1). A dual or unit augmented form for a single person category in the paradigm is *not* sufficient for a 1 code.

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Clarifying comments: Demonstratives are modifiers that can modify nouns (of any type and not just a restricted set such as location nouns) to mark position (e.g. deixis or reference within discourse). This doesn't have to be only Euclidean distance (meters, inches etc.), it could also be concerned with near or far in relation to the interlocutors (cf. Wolof). If the system of demonstratives includes a marker that is anaphoric this does not count as a third distance.

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Clarifying comments: Elevation is concerned with how high up or low an object is (altitude).

Feature: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Clarifying comments: Is there a distinction visible-non-visible when referencing to items that are in the same relative distance, i.e. it is not relevant that demonstratives denoting far away reference often also imply non-visibility.

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns whether there exists a classifier system in which classifiers appear with demonstratives to classify the noun. This classifier system can be symmetrical with numeral, possessive or verbal classifiers. It is sufficient if they sometimes occur. Please note, this feature does not concern gender/noun classes and agreement with the noun class, but a separate nominal classifier system.

Feature: Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Clarifying comments: Are there different number markers for a single number category? And is the choice between these markers unpredictable from the marker a noun receives in another number category? For example, are there different plural markers while there is only one (or no) singular marker? Or do two nouns receive different singular markers but the same plural marker? This feature targets bound number markers, free number markers, and clitics.

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Clarifying comments: Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group. Only so called "strong suppletion" counts here.  Only answer (1) if there are more than three examples of this. Body-parts and kinship terms are good place to start investigating.

Feature: Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of singular number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking does not count for a 1 here (hence the emphasis on "overt" in the feature question). This feature is in contrast to [GB316 Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB316) which focuses on the non-bound marking of singular number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of dual number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB317 Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element? ](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB317) which focuses on the non-bound marking of dual number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of plural number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB318	Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element? ](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB318) which focusses on the non-bound marking of plural number.  For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1. Furthermore, for this feature reduplication only isn't enough.  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature aims to cover markers or markings that instead of signalling additive plural - "several instances of X" marks that the reference contains entities associated with X - "X and other people/things associated with X’. For example, "the King-s went to the market" means there were several of the type "king" that went. An associative plural interpretation of "s" would be "the King and his entourage went to the market". This marker does not need to be bound to the noun. If the additive plural also has this function, this also counts.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An action nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an action or state. In English, we can exemplify this with "the enemy’s **destruction** of the city" Arrive -arriving would also serves as an example, or 'La concentracio´n de Sherlock Holmes duro´ cinco horas' in Spanish (‘Sherlock Holmes’ concentration lasted five hours’). There needs to be productive derivation, but they can also refer to states or events - not just actions. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "action/state/event" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An agent nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an agent of an action. In English, we can exemplify this with the productive _-er_ suffix (_baker, fisher, gardener_ etc.). There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "person" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Clarifying comments: An object nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes the object/result of an action. There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "thing" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether biological sex is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their biological sex for this feature to be coded 1. That is, sex must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the shape of an object is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their shape for this feature to be coded 1. That is, shape must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the animacy of a noun is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their animacy for this feature to be coded 1. That is, animacy must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Note that while (biological) sex is generally associated with animate referents, a gender system that makes a distinction between male and female is not necessarily sufficient to trigger a 1 here. A gender system in which animacy is a relevant factor will often make a distinction between human or animal referents and non-living referents, and animate status may be extended to culturally important non-living entities (e.g. mythological figures) or objects (e.g. celestial bodies). A human/non-human distinction is sufficient for a 1 code.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether belonging to the kingdom of plants is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for nouns that refer to plants to be classified in certain gender categories for this feature to be coded 1. That is, plant status must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Are there numeral classifiers?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns whether numerals take an element that varies depending on the noun used, and is not the same as a gender system used in the language (i.e. is not numeral agreement with gender).

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns whether there exists an independent classifier system in possessive constructions that is not related to the other classifier systems such as the gender/noun class of the language or numeral classifiers.  We are concerned with markers that signal the nature of the possessor or the possessum (possessor classifiers/possessed classifiers). This feature applies to both pronominal/nominal possessors and markers which are bound or free. Possessive classifiers need not be obligatory, it can also be possible to construct possessive phrases without possessive classifiers.  Differences in the expression of individual, joint, separate and group possession are not relevant here.

Feature: Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Clarifying comments: Is there a morpho-syntactic difference in attributive possession that can be ascribed to alienability?  This feature applies to constructions with both pronominal and nominal possessors.  Typically, inalienable possession applies to the semantic domains of body parts and kinship, but it is sometimes found in other categories that don't align perfectly with the canonical notion of 'alienability', such as part-whole relationships other than body parts, social relationships other than kinship, or things inherently linked to a person (e.g. a person's voice, mental states, or other attributes).  This feature targets splits in possessive marking strategy where different classes of possessum are associated with different constructions, and where one of those possessum classes includes body parts and/or kinship terms, and possibly other categories that have strong semantic associations with their owners, social relationships, or part-whole relationships.

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature focuses on the relative order of possessor and possessum (i.e. that which is possessed) in an adnominal possession construction. Coding should take into consideration only those possession constructions that are pragmatically unmarked (i.e. not focus). This feature applies to both nominal possessors and independent pronominal possessors. Affixal marking of possession, by contrast, is coded in features GB430-GB433.

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Clarifying comments: Do core adjectives used as predicates take on verbal morphology? The predicative adjectives need not take exactly all verbal marking. If there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival predicates share, this counts as 1 (for example, if a language has "he runs" and "he greens"). This should apply to most verbs in the language. If there is additional morphology or there are additional elements that the adjective requires, then this feature should be coded as 0.
Function: predication, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Clarifying comments: Do elements expressing attributive adjectival meaning receive the same treatment as verbs when verbs are used attributively, i.e. inside an NP? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking. If there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. The result need not be finite, participles would count if that is the way verbs are marked when used attributively. This means that if the language in question forms modifying verbs by participles (“running man”) and this is the same for adjectival roots (“redding man”) then there is a yes here.
Function: attribution, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. S is the single argument of an intransitive verb. P is the patient-like argument of a transitive verb. A is the agent-like argument of a transitive verb. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S NPs, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for independent personal pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: This question is about independent pronouns only; indexes are irrelevant here. Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. S is the single argument of an intransitive verb. P is the patient-like argument of a transitive verb. A is the agent-like argument of a transitive verb. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S pronouns, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, etc.). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, etc. Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for independent oblique personal pronominal arguments (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying comments: Are independent personal pronouns morphologically marked for oblique case (i.e. not S/A/P)? Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, etc.). Suppletion also counts as case marking for this feature. Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, etc. Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.

Feature: Are there prepositions?
Clarifying comments: Prepositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They precede the noun phrase they occur with. Proclitics (case markers that only occur noun phrase initially) count as prepositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as prepositions. If there is only one preposition, this is enough for a 1 here.

Feature: Are there postpositions?
Clarifying comments: Postpositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They follow the noun phrase they occur with. Enclitics (markers that only occur noun phrase finally) count as postpositions in Grambank. This means that [phonological boundness](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as postpositions. If there is only one postposition, this is enough for a 1 here.

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that only mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Clarifying comments: These [prefixes or proclitics](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Affixes-clitics) could have a variety of functions, marking TAME, functioning as verbal derivation markers, as inverse markers, relative markers, etc. Only indexes dedicated to a single person do not count. The end result has to be a finite verb and cannot, for example, be a deverbal noun or an adverb.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change

Feature: Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that only mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Clarifying comments: These [suffixes or enclitics](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Affixes-clitics) could have a variety of functions, marking TAME, functioning as verbal derivation markers, as inverse markers, relative markers, etc. Only indexes dedicated to a single person do not count. The end result has to be a finite verb and cannot, for example, be a deverbal noun or an adverb.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change

Feature: Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Clarifying comments: This affix must be stem-internal and dedicated to a particular purpose, either derivational or inflectional (see general definitions for more information on productivity and dedicated functions). In keeping with existing data, if the only infixation process described for a language involves reduplication, please code 0 but be sure to note in the comments field that infixing reduplication is present.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Clarifying comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of present tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question then such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.  Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for GB082, but (0) for [GB084 (future tense)](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Clarifying comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing overt marking of past tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that past tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.  It can be difficult to distinguish perfective/perfect/punctual aspect from past tense, since past tense tends to be perfective. If this is an issue, bring it up for discussion.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Clarifying comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of future tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.  Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for [GB082](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB082), but (0) for this feature (GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.  It can be hard to distinguish future tense from different modal categories, after all if something is in the future it has not yet occurred and can be construed as something wished for, planned, intended etc rather than actually on the concrete timeline of events. This is why it's necessary to take extra notice on sections on mood, especially irrealis, when coding for future tense.  If a language only has future tense under negation, this does not count for this feature. It needs to be present for affirmation as well. [This was brought up in this issue thread.](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/issues/62) The reason for this is that conditions such as "only under negation" are likely to give rise to quite different analysis by different linguists (hence hard to ensure comparability) and might also be overlooked. If we were to treat such marginal cases as "1" we would most likely have to go back to a lot of the cases that were coded as "0" and re-evaluate their coding more thoroughly.

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Clarifying comments: This feature is concerned with bound marking of imperfective/perfective grammatical aspects. These categories could go by the name of punctual/continuous, preterit/progressive etc. The answer could be "yes" even if it's only one that is overtly marked, i.e. if imperfective is by affix and perfective by auxiliary for example. Please take notice that GB310 and GB86 are not covering exactly the same functions, they cover more grammatical aspects than punctual/continuous. If this marking is only relevant for a small subset of verbs, alert patron and discuss.  If this distinction is only available in some TAM-conditions, this counts as well. For example, if there isn't an aspectual distinction in the past but only in the present, this still triggers a '1'.

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple independent clause?
Clarifying comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Clarifying comments: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**  “Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes.  This pattern includes some of the cases referred to as (alignment) split in the literature. Polarity (i.e. positive vs. negative distinction) does not count as a TAM category. Absence of overt indexing in the imperative does not count here either.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, person, number, gender

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Clarifying comments: Marking strategies include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. The distinction between intransitive and transitive verbs is not included here. "Variations in marking strategies" include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". For languages to be coded "1" the respective verb classes need to be of a substantial size (several dozens verbs or more) and ideally represent a productive pattern. The presence of small verb classes with whose members are often exhaustively listed in a descriptive grammar and are presented as an exceptional patterns does not qualify as "1". The patterns of interest is more common with intransitive verbs and include cases of the so-called active-inactive alignment (or simply: active or agentive-patientive or stative-active) in cases of differentially marked S argument. Some grammars use the terms unergative-unaccusative verbs. The pattern of interest is, however, not restricted to the S argument and variations in marking of A and P arguments are also included.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, verb classification, person, number, gender

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Clarifying comments: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**  “Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". This pattern includes cases referred to as person-based (alignment) split and hierarchical alignment in the literature.
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, person, number, gender

Feature: Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Clarifying comments: Do some verbs have two or more suppletive allomorphs whose distribution is conditioned by the person of an S, A, or P argument? Suppletive are allomorphs which are not similar in pronunciation, i.e. cannot be related to each other by morpho-phonological rules? The question covers both strong and weak suppletion, as well as ablaut. There must be at least **three** verbs to code 1.

Feature: Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has a benefactive argument. The marker could be analyzed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the benefactor or benefactee. Serial verb constructions that include a marker of benefactive (typically the root for "give") do not count here.
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, benefactive, derivation, valency increase

Feature: Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals that the verb has an instrumental argument. The marker could be analysed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the instrument.
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, instrumental, derivation, valency increase

Feature: Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Clarifying comments: GB105 is concerned with both flagging (i.e. case and adposition marking) and indexing on the verb of the respective arguments. "1" is firstly triggered by flagging. Only if there is no overt flagging for the P argument and the recipient argument, indexing is considered. "1" includes both the "double-object construction" and the "secondary-object construction" of Haspelmath (2013).  Consider as ditransitive only verbs expressing physical transfer of possession or mental transfer of message (give, lend, hand, feed, send, bring, show, tell, teach).  Consider as ditransitive verbs which allow overt expression of an agent, a theme and a recipient/addressee arguments as separate NPs. The morphological marking of these arguments (e.g. dative case vs. adpositional marking) is irrelevant for counting a verb as ditransitive.
Relevant unit(s): noun, NP, verb, index, case marker
Function: argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification, derivation

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation, i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). The marker has to form a phonological unit with the root, be it by affixation, cliticisation, suppletion, reduplication, tone etc. If the verb that the marker is attached to is described as an "auxiliary", this also counts but it is advisable to bring this up for discussion.

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns a [bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) verbal marker that signals the direction or location of the event/state/action that the predicate is referencing. A marker that just indicates that something happens in "multiple directions" does not count here.
Function: argument marking, oblique, applicative, valency change, derivation, valency increase

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Clarifying comments: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the number (singular, dual, plural etc) of a participant? The participant triggering the suppletive choice could be any of A, P, or S. Auxiliary verbs are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts. There should be at least three verbs with participant number suppletion to count as 1.

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Clarifying comments: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the tense or aspect (present, past etc) form it occurs in? Auxiliary verbs are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts. The language should have at least three cases, i.e., three verbs, to count as 'yes' (so there should be three cases exemplified or implied in the description).

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Clarifying comments: Are there different groups of verbs that take different finiteness markers on the verb. Phonological rules are not considered here, we are concerned with whether there is non-phonological allomorphy of finiteness marking on verbs depending on which verb is chosen. Tonal classes are particles which may encode finiteness, and can be considered. Please note that a class of suppletive verbs does not count here.  Look for finiteness markers such as: * Person : 1st, 2nd, 3rd * Number: singular, plural, dual and trial. * Gender: masculine, feminine or neuter * Tense: present, past, or future. * Aspect: perfect, perfective, progressive. * Mood : indicative, subjunctive, imperative, optative. * Voice: active, middle, or passive.
Function: TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, verb classification, argument marking, core, oblique

Feature: Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether intransitive verbs can take a [bound morpheme](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) that implies the addition of just one role in the event denoted by the verb. This could be a causative affix or clitic, an applicative (benefactive, instrumental, ...), ... It has to be productive. Note that there is no logical dependency with GB155 here, as a language could have causatives that change a verb's valency from 2 to 3 but not from 1 to 2.
Function: valency change, derivation, valency increase, causative, applicative

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Clarifying comments: Reflexive markers indicate that a participant is coreferential with another participant in the clause or sentence (cf. Haspelmath & The APiCS Consortium 2013). This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. Reduplication of verbs also counts. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language.
Function: reflexive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Clarifying comments: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized. This feature targets [phonologically bound]( https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers.
Function: reflexive, reciprocal, valency change, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Clarifying comments: This questions aims at capturing verbal classifier systems.  These systems are not based on agreement with the noun class system (Aikhenvald 2000:149). The system can however be identical or very similar to the possessive, numeral or demonstrative classifier systems.

Feature: Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Clarifying comments: Is there a copula in use (in an equative sentence) when the predicate is nominal? This copula does not have to be obligatory, nor a finite verb, it could be a demonstrative. Please note that adjectives are not included within the category of 'nominals' here.

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Clarifying comments: Serial verbs are two or more verbs in juxtaposition, functioning as a single predicate. Some languages allow intervening material and others do not. There is no morphology to mark their relationship with each other. Each of the verbs is a separate phonological word but the construction as a whole is expressed in one intonational unit. Morphology is shared to a greater or lesser extent.  Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.

Feature: Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they fulfilled our criteria of "inflecting word".  While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.  A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably inflecting words marking tense.

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Clarifying comments: Verbal compounding is two or more verb stems acting as one phonological and grammatical word. Verb compounds share the same arguments. Languages with serial verbs can often have verb compounds too, however they might not always be described as such.  Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Clarifying comments: [new summary from Jakob:] https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/730  A light-verb construction is a complex predicate with two components: (1) a lexical stem which is not a verb and (2) an inflectable verb, which is called the light verb. The light verb makes no lexical semantic or functional semantic contribution to the complex predicate. It only serves as a placeholder for verbal inflection. It only makes the lexical stem function as a verb. Light verbs are the analytical counterparts of (denominal) verbalizers. They make a 'non-verb' function as a 'verb', and that is the only thing they do. Items that can occur as lexical stems in light-verb constructions are: (1) nouns (e.g. 'do baby' in Ivorian English or 'have sex' in English for 'to copulate'), (2) adjectives (e.g. 'make beatiful' in English), (3) non-inflectable items such as ideophones (e.g. 'do ssss' for 'to make an ssss sound'), or (4) verbs borrowed from other languages that do not inflect in the target language. Regular verbs cannot occur as lexical stems in light-verb constructions. This is the main difference between light-verb constructions and serial verb constructions. Serial verb constructions may contain verbs that lexico-semantically contribute to the meaning of the clause. Light-verb constructions may not. Light verbs are different from auxiliaries in that auxiliaries add a functional specification to the clause (e.g. tense, aspect, modality, negation), while light verbs don't add any such functional-semantic values to the clause.   This question concerns constructions involving a non-predicating element expressing the lexical meaning of the construction, in conjunction with a semantically fairly empty verb, which enables the element to function as a predicate by providing the necessary morphology, e.g. 'eye do' for 'see'; or 'sneeze hit' for 'sneeze'. Exclude constructions that fall into the categories of verb compounding, clause-chaining, auxiliaries and serial verbs are excluded from the category of "light-verb". The verb needs to be sufficiently productive, it cannot only concern a few instances. It is uninteresting whether the predicating element is of nominal/verbal/other root. This means for example that what is described in the literature as "co-verb constructions" most likely are a subcategory of light verbs. It is also uninteresting for the definition of light-verbs whether or not the non-finite predicating element can occur outside the construction or not, both scenarios are acceptable. The category of light verbs cannot all consist of constructions describing states, there has to be at least a few dynamic events. There should also be instances where it is hard to define whether the non-finite predicating element (adjunct) is clearly nominal or not.

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Clarifying comments: Noun-verb incorporation is defined as a special construction where obligatorily bare (i.e. articleless, numberless, modifierless) nouns must occur adjacent to or inside of the verb (in a fixed order). This question asks essentially, can transitive verbs become intransitive by means of noun incorporation, and is this process productive? This need not be the default productive way of intransitivizing nouns, but the process must be productive. The incorporated noun is semantically the direct object of the verb. For example: "he was painting the bike" = "he was bike-painting". Noun incorporation where the noun is acting as modifier do not count, such as "she was running like Jacob runs" = "she was Jacob-running". If it is necessary to still overtly mark the direct object, for example with a pronoun, that does not count.

Feature: Is there an existential verb?
Clarifying comments: Is there an element expressing existential predication ("God **exists**/There **is** a God"), that is **different from the equative or attributive copula**? It is possible that there are more than one existential verbs making further distinctions, temporary versus permanent existence or a special marker for negative existence. The existential marker can be used for the expression of other functions, such as aspect, as long as it is **not** identical to the copula of identity or attribution ("God **is** Jesus" and "God **is** great"). The existential element need not fulfilled all formal criteria for being a "verb". The existence of a negative existential alone is not sufficient for a 1, locational/positional verbs are also not enough for a 1.

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Clarifying comments: English would receive 0 here, as you can simply say that 'a bottle is on the table'. Dutch would be coded as 1, as you always have to specify whether an object 'stands' or 'lies' on the table (you cannot say that it 'is' on the table). Different configurations are possible, however (e.g. 'sit' vs. 'stand', 'hang' vs. 'lie' vs. 'stand'). Note that this feature does not concern morphological (or other overt) marking for position or shape, but really the use of different verbs for this purpose (in other words, suppletion). If the posture verbs are clearly dominant in frequency this is sufficient to count as 'obligatory' for the purpose of this question, even if non-posture alternatives are grammatical.

Feature: Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
Clarifying comments: Some languages have verb few members of the word class which is most commonly known as "verbs". In such languages, it is typically the case that what is described by one verb in other languages is instead expressed by so called "light verb constructions" (GB123), e.g., 'do meeting' for 'meet'. If a language has a small number of verbs in this sense, typically it will says that there is a closed class of verbs and a large part of the grammar will be devoted to the constructions whereby a verb from the closed class combines with an open-class item to form the predicate in most sentences. If the grammar never remarks on the size of the verbal inventory this almost always means that the language does not have a small number of verbs in the sense of the present question.

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Clarifying comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Clarifying comments: Whatever the order in main clauses is, does it change in subordinate clauses? For example, is the order between woman/man/chases the same in 'the woman chases the man' versus 'I think that the woman chases the man'. It is sufficient for a 1 if there are different options in subordinate clauses that are not available in main clauses.

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Clarifying comments: By clausal objects here we mean clauses that are directly governed by a finite verb (typically verbs of 'wanting', 'saying' etc.). In other words, complement subordinate clauses and not relative clauses. For example, _I like apples_ (nominal object) versus _I like that you play the piano every morning_ (clausal object) are in the same position (SVO). Many of the languages that do change are SOV languages that have SVO for (long) clausal objects. The question aims at discerning whether they are treated like prototypical nominal direct objects (not indirect or obliques). This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this.

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Clarifying comments: The order is fixed if you cannot permute the order of core constituents and the verb without either i) changing the propositional content of the clause or ii) requiring intonational signalling or further elements (particles, cleft components, adjuncts).

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. The position "clause-final" includes suffixes on verbs in verb-final clauses, even if it isn't indeed the very last suffix on the verb. Prefixes on clause-final verbs do not count as clause-final negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-final, this is sufficient to count as clause-final negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Clarifying comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood. It is possible that SN is used for other kinds of negation as well, this is a necessary requirement but not exhaustive. This includes prefixes on clause-initial verbs, but suffixes on clause-initial verbs do not count as clause-initial negation. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-initial, this is sufficient to count as clause-initial negation and trigger a 1 for this feature. As with other word order features in this dataset, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or marked focus constructions.

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Clarifying comments: Is the negative construction for declarative negation ("I don't drink") different from negative imperative ("don't drink!"). This feature covers more than only different negators: different order, loss of finiteness or addition of new elements would also suffice. If the analysis of the language-specific researcher results in two different forms for negative imperative and prohibitive, then we are only concerned with the construction that is fulfilling the traditional imperative function here.

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Clarifying comments: This feature pertains only to the negative marker itself, be it an independent particle, verb, auxiliary, clitic or affix. By non-verbal here we are referring to locational ("The dog is in the kitchen"), existential ("There is a heaven") or nominal predication ("Ursula is a witch"). Negation of possession, attributives (adjectives) capability or knowing are not included. However, it is very likely that languages that have different negation from the standard negator for these functions also make a distinction between locational/existential and standard.

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Clarifying comments: In a number of languages, predicates referring to uncontrolled events or states are encoded differently from those that refer to controlled events. Often, such a distinction surfaces in predicates referring to sensations (such as hunger, thirst, pain, cold, cramps, sleepiness ...), emotions (anger, happiness), or cognitive states (forgetting, remembering). Such uncontrolled predicates may be found in special constructions, different case frames ('sleep hits me', 'cramp footgrabs me'), they may form a special conjugation class of verbs or adjectives, there may be a dedicated (modal) marker for control vs. non-control, etc. The existence of verbal derivations such as passive or causative does not count as 1 here.
Relevant unit(s): clause, verb, adjective, noun, case marker, NP
Function: control, argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification
Form: special construction, flagging, indexing, conjugation, declension

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Clarifying comments: Passivization is a detransitivizing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) passive markers on lexical verbs. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here.
Function: valency change, passive, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Clarifying comments: An antipassive marker detransitivizes verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique. In a construction with ergative alignment, this means that the A argument of a transitive clause is encoded as the S argument in a corresponding antipassive clause. An antipassive marker often also has other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, this feature targets any intransitivising marker that is not, or not only, a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets productive [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) antipassive markers on lexical verbs, as well as reduplication. Zero-marking or the removal of a transitivizing marker is not sufficient for a 1. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here. If the antipassive marker is only applied in a limited set of probably lexicalized items, it does not trigger 1.
Function: valency change, antipassive, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Clarifying comments: Inverse systems are based on an animacy, person, or topicality hierarchy. Inverse markers indicate that the patient outranks the agent on the hierarchy. In a system that has a hierarchy "speech act participants > 3SG pronouns > humans > animals, etc.", for example, 'man INV-bite dog' would mean 'the dog bit the man'. Note that in some languages, there are portmanteau morphemes that both function as person indexes on verbs and as direct/inverse markers. They would trigger 1 for this question. This feature targets [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) inverse markers.

Feature: Is there clause chaining?
Clarifying comments: Clause-chaining here is not just juxtapositioning of minimal clauses with no connectors, but chains of medial clauses (i.e. formally reduced clauses that do not have the full marking that usually occurs on the verb) which are dependent on a single verb that often (but not always) occurs in a final position. This complete verb is fully specified to provide the missing categories (e.g. TAM, argument marking) for the entire clause chain. Clause chains may be referred to as topic chains, or as sequences of medial clauses/medial verbs. Crucially, this construction involves a single independent verb form, with several medial verbs that are dependent on it for full specification. Clause chains are generally used to describe simple sequences of events, and the medial verbs involved are often marked by special affixes.  Some analyses assert that medial verbs are coordinated, or at the very least not subordinated. However, it can be very difficult to determine this from descriptions and examples in grammars. Here we focus less on these syntactic distinctions and more on surface forms that fit the above description (sequences of stripped down verb forms dependent on a single verb for full specification), used for describing simple sequences of events.  In some cases clause-chaining may be difficult to distinguish from serial verb constructions. Remember that a serial verb construction involves a set of verbs or verb phrases that are typically inflected identically for TAM in a single clause, whereas clause-chaining involves a set of formally reduced clauses involving unmarked verbs, all dependent on a single fully specified verb form. Clause-chaining is also different from verb compounding, in that the verbs involved in clause-chaining all carry full semantic weight (in contrast to the light verb of verb compounding) and different arguments (e.g. objects) may occur in each clause (whereas a verb compound takes a single set of arguments as a whole). In cases where it is unclear which of these constructions is represented by the examples in the grammar, a (?) may be coded, but be sure to indicate in the comments that you were unable to determine which of these constructions is demonstrated in the relevant examples.

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Clarifying comments: Is there an overt marker on the verb that marks whether the argument has the same/different referent as an argument of the following clause? Some languages (e.g. Kashaya) signal switch reference by using different allomorphs of TAM markers depending on whether the subject of the following clause is the same or different. Some systems (e.g. Southeastern Pomo) only have special morphology to indicate different subjects, whereas the contrasting morphological pattern that is used for same subjects can also be used for some combinations of clauses with different referents.

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with whether there is an overt marker dedicated to signaling the distinction between temporally simultaneous and sequential actions. If sequential meaning is a secondary function of an imperfective aspect this does not count; it must be indicated by a devoted marker. The language does not need to express both sequential and simultaneous temporal relationships overtly; one marker devoted to either function is sufficient to trigger a 1 code.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Clarifying comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer core argument that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are targeted by this question. This question targets productive, [phonologically bound](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) causative markers. Lexicalized causative verbs should be disregarded for this feature.
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Clarifying comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are included in this feature. This question targets causative constructions that feature an element that clearly originated as a verb that means or meant 'to say' (e.g. 'I said for the stone to fall' to mean 'I made the stone fall'). Note that, exceptionally, for this feature, constructions that appear to be synchronically fossilized but were clearly productive in the past also count.
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Clarifying comments: A verb is reduplicated if its root is fully or partially repeated. The word class of the outcome of the process is not relevant, as long as the root is a verb. Full repetition of already inflected verbs or whole phrases does not trigger a 1 for this feature. This feature only targets [productive](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Productively) reduplication. Lexicalized examples are irrelevant.

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?
Clarifying comments: A noun is reduplicated if its root is fully or partially repeated. The word class of the outcome of the process is not relevant, as long as the root is a noun. Full repetition of already inflected nouns or whole phrases does not trigger a 1 for this feature. This feature only targets [productive](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Productively) reduplication. Lexicalized examples are irrelevant.

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Clarifying comments: A lexeme is reduplicated if its root is fully or partially repeated. The word class of the outcome of the process is not relevant, as long as the root is not a noun or a verb. Reduplication of function words counts, as does reduplication of numerals, adjectives and adverbs. Full repetition of already inflected words or whole phrases does not trigger a 1 for this feature. This feature only targets [productive](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/Productively) reduplication. Lexicalized examples are irrelevant.

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of trial number on nouns. The marker should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB319	Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB319) which focuses on the non-bound marking of trial number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class.
