It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns bound grammatical marking of paucal (From Latin _paucalis_ meaning “few, little”) number on nouns, i.e. a number marker that is unspecified as to exact amount, but more than one and usually less than 10 (depending on what is being counted). This feature is in contrast to [GB320 Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB320) which focuses on the non-bound marking of paucal number. For more on bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology'). If there is only bound marking of number on nouns derived from other word classes (such as adjectives or verbs), that does not suffice for a 1.  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Logophoric pronouns are used distinguish reference to an individual whose speech or thought or feeling is being reported from other third-person referents. Unsurprisingly, then, logophoric pronouns are commonly found in reported speech contexts. This question concerns the existence of an anaphoric pronoun that specifically receives its referential identity from the subject of the superordinate clause in a reported speech construction (i.e. the speaker/thinker/feeler). In other words, is there a special pronominal form that occurs in the complement clause of a speech or thought verb, that designates the subject of the speech/thought verb as its referent (as opposed to any other referent)?

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: For this feature, we are interested in noun classes (classes which nouns belong to based upon properties such as gender, animacy, or shape and can be identified through agreement with a modifier). We are not looking at noun classifiers (classifiers classify the noun and occur independently from other elements). This feature asks whether adjectives (defined semantically as 'adnominal property words') show agreement with the gender of nouns they modify. This should be true for more than a small class of semantically restricted adjectives; English 'blond' v. 'blonde' for example would not be enough to answer 1 for the question. There should be a fixed number (i.e. a fixed number of genders, as opposed to them being noun classifiers, totalling up to 30).

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Demonstratives are modifiers that can modify nouns to mark position. This feature is looking to see if demonstratives can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Articles can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class. This feature concerns both definite and indefinite articles. Features [GB020](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB020) and [GB021](https://github.com/grambank/grambank/wiki/GB021) both concern the absence or presence of definite and indefinite articles, please consider those features if you have coded 1 for this feature.

Feature: Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Clarifying comments: Does animacy of an argument (S or A or P) determines the form or presence of the indexing on the verb. This system of marking has to be unrelated or not reducible to the gender/noun class system as revealed by agreement in the noun phrase.

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: Adnominal property words semantically roughly correspond to adjectives in those languages that have this word class. The property word can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number.

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: We are interested in seeing whether adnominal demonstratives (not pronominal demonstratives) can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying comments: Articles (a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity, (in)definiteness and information status) can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. This includes both definite and indefinite articles.

Feature: Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying comments: Diminutive marking encodes smaller size. This marker must be phonologically bound [on the noun](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence). The marker may also encode other meanings but needs to minimally encode smaller size. Reduplication, and stem changes count. This needs to be a productive pattern.

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying comments: Augmentative marking generally intensifies the noun (in various ways). To code 1, the marker needs to minimally encode a large size of the noun it is attached to. This needs to be a productive pattern.

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the phonological properties of the noun are one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their phonological properties for this feature to be coded 1. That is, some phonological property of a noun must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Examples of phonological properties that may play a role in gender/class assignment include tone or initial consonants. Note that noun class/gender morphology may create phonological similarities across members of a certain noun class or gender; however, this is not sufficient for a 1 coding for this feature. Phonological properties must contribute to the categorization of nouns to classes/genders, rather than simply result from associated morphology.

Feature: What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Clarifying comments: Adnominal property words semantically roughly correspond to adjectives in those languages that have this word class. We want to include elements that mark "adjectival" function but that might not be described as "adjectives", see [GB069](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB069). The question concerns the pragmatically neutral order(s).

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for second person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of second person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for second person singular, but not second person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular second person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for first person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of first person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for first person singular, but not first person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular first person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.

Feature: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: This applies to cardinal numbers primarily. A system of numeral classifiers (GB057) cannot be coded as a system of agreement in gender/noun class.

Feature: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature is concerned with the ordering of a universal quantifier ('all') and the noun. We are specifically focused on adnominal quantification in pragmatically unmarked contexts. In languages that do not have a distinction between collective and distributive universal quantifiers ('all' vs. 'every'), a quantifier that could be translated as 'all' and has a primarily plural use will be a sufficient target for this feature.  There are four possible codes for this feature, reflecting the fact that the collective universal quantifier might occur strictly before or strictly after the noun, may be allowed in both of these relative positions, or may not be present in a language. A 0 code is also applicable when the language does not allow a basic construction with an adnominal collective universal quantifier and a noun (e.g. if only a floating construction is used).  Orders that result from constructions like quantifier float (e.g. English "The children have all come") should be disregarded for the purposes of coding this feature.

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies languages that use different forms or syntax for collective universal quantification versus distributive universal quantification. This contrasts with languages that use both the same form *and* the same syntactic position for these two types of quantification.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. For this feature, we are looking for a verb that expresses predicative possession where the possessor is the subject, the possessum the object and the verb is finite and clearly transitive. The finite element in itself need not be clearly distinct from an existential or locational predicator, the main difference is the argument structure. Transitivity is a language-specific category that needs to be investigated separately to learn whether or not the construction is transitive. In case of languages where transitivity is hard to define it might be beneficial to compare to verbs of "hold" and "grasp". It is very likely that habeo-verb constructions arise from possessive constructions where the possessor is expressed as a topic (see feature 255).  This is known as "have-possessive" in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature is concerned with construction where the possessum is the subject of an existential/locative predicate and the possessor is in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "at/in/on" (i.e. "a car is on me") or there is a locative marker on the verb. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for location, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.  This is known as "locational possessive" in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, locative

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject of an existential predicative and the possessor in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "to/for" (i.e. "a car is to me") or dative case. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for dative case, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.  This is known as "dative possessive", a subcategory of "locational possessive", in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, dative

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and possessum. This feature concerns constructions where the possessum is the subject and the possessor is not in a separate noun phrase but instead a modifier to the possessum. The possessor is construed as a modifier of the possessum (i.e. "my car exists").  This is known as "genitive possessive" in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, genitive

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation between a possessor and a possessum. This feature concerns a construction where the possessum is coded lika a comitative argument. This kind of construction is also known as "conjunctional possessive". The possessor is the subject, the predicate is an existential/locational/copula verb and the possessum is marked by an element marking simultaneity between clauses, or "also/too", or subordinating conjunction ("when/while"), or coordinating particle ("and"), or a comitative marker {"with"). The conjugational/comitative/coordination/topical/simultaneity marking need not be phonologically bound to the possessum-NP, but it needs to mark the possessum-NP.  This is known as "conjunctional possessive" in the work of Stassen.
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, comitative

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Clarifying comments: For this feature, we are looking for polar interrogation marked by intonation, and it should be the only marker in that construction. However, it does not have to be the only construction in the language which can mark polar interrogation. Intonation is our focus and not tone. Intonation is different from tonal marking. Tonal marking is bound to a certain position in the clause (e.g. the final syllable, or a certain constituent). Intonation concerns the whole clause and will have a variation in pitch across sentences and phrases.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Clarifying comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative.  There is allowed to be a different intonation from declarative sentences.

Feature: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying comments: In this feature, we are looking for a polar interrogative particle which appears at the beginning of the clause. The particle should be dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of an affirmative or negative answer (as opposed to content questions).  Matthew Dryer distinguished **neutral** questions from **leading** questions in the paragraph quoted below from [WALS Chapter 92](https://wals.info/chapter/92), and this feature in Grambank concerns neutral questions:  "Many languages have question particles or expressions that indicate that the question is a leading question, one where the speaker has an expectation as to what the answer will be. English, for example, employs what are called “tag-questions” for this purpose, illustrated in (13a), which differ from the neutral question form illustrated in (13b) in that its form indicates that the speaker expects a ‘yes’ answer.  13a. You’re planning to go to the beach, aren’t you?  13b. Are you planning to go to the beach?"

Feature: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying comments: Is there a particle that occurs at the end of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Clarifying comments: Is there a particle that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions) that most commonly occurs in the middle of the clause, neither initially nor finally?  (Definition from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').  Matthew Dryer distinguished **neutral** questions from **leading** questions in the paragraph quoted below from [WALS Chapter 92](https://wals.info/chapter/92), and this feature in Grambank concerns neutral questions:  "Many languages have question particles or expressions that indicate that the question is a leading question, one where the speaker has an expectation as to what the answer will be. English, for example, employs what are called “tag-questions” for this purpose, illustrated in (13a), which differ from the neutral question form illustrated in (13b) in that its form indicates that the speaker expects a ‘yes’ answer.  13a. You’re planning to go to the beach, aren’t you?  13b. Are you planning to go to the beach?"

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies languages that have a comparative construction that involves a form (usually a verb form) meaning 'surpass' or 'exceed'. Typically, the standard of comparison is the direct object, the thing which is being compared to that standard is the subject, and there are two predicates: one expressing 'surpass/exceed', and one carrying relevant lexical information about the property under comparison (e.g. "Ronald exceed be-tall Julia").  Though this typical structure is quite common in languages that have a 'surpass/exceed' comparative construction, only the use of a 'surpass/exceed' form is required for this feature; it is not necessary for the standard to occur as a direct object or the thing being compared to serve as the subject in order to trigger a 1 value. The order of these predicates is not relevant for this feature, nor whether the property word is a verb or an adjective. The predicate expressing 'surpass/exceed' must also have functions besides comparison.

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies comparative constructions that mark the standard of reference with an element that is otherwise locational or benefactive in meaning. In these constructions the standard NP is invariably constructed with a marker that also has a locational/adverbial function. Please note that benefactive markers are included here, following Stassen's category of locational comparatives. The marker of the property word is irrelevant for this feature (i.e. "tall-er").
Function: comparison, predication, argument marking, oblique, locative

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Clarifying comments: Is there a comparative construction comprised of two conjoined clauses? Specifically, this construction must involve two conjoined clauses, one with the standard-NP and one with the comparee-NP. These NPs have the same function in the clauses. Note that many if not most languages can juxtapose clauses in order to make comparisons (e.g. English "She is nice and he is not nice"). Here we are focused on languages that have a dedicated comparative construction with this structure.

Feature: Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Clarifying comments: This question is focused on comparative constructions that have a dedicated marker for the standard of comparison that does not fall under the umbrella of the locational comparative (GB266) or surpass/exceed comparative (GB255). Note that a language may have multiple comparative constructions, including a non-locational, non-surpass/exceed comparative as well as constructions that are described by those features.  Crucially the dedicated marker in this construction must not elsewhere have a surpass/exceed meaning or a locational meaning. It may, however, have other functions (e.g. temporal adverb or conjunction, among other possibilities). It is irrelevant whether this marker is phonologically free or not or whether it triggers agreement in case, gender, etc.  Historically, comparative constructions with dedicated markers (sometimes called "particle comparatives") grammaticalize from constructions of conjoined clauses. An example of a particle comparative would be the Germanic languages, such as English "than". Note that the marking of the property word is not relevant here (i.e. "tall-er").
Relevant unit(s): verb, auxiliary, particle, clause, adjective, adposition

Feature: Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying comments: This feature focuses on the presence of a bound marker of comparative degree on the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. -er in English "tall-er"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. "Maria is taller"). This feature requires the degree marker to be phonologically bound to the property word.

Feature: Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying comments: This feature focuses on the presence of a phonologically non-bound marker of comparative degree that modifies the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. French "plus grand"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller"). The comparative constructions of interest express superiority (as in the French and English examples above), not inferiority (e.g. meanings like "John is less athletic than Maria"). Superlative forms  This feature requires that the degree marker modify the property word, but not be phonologically bound.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Clarifying comments: For this feature, we are looking for polar interrogation marked by a question particle and verbal morphology, these should be the only two markers in the construction. However, it does not have to be the only construction in the language which can mark polar interrogation. Nominalizers also count as verbal morphology for the purpose of this question. Tone does not count as a particle here. The intonation of the clause is not relevant to this question. It may be the same as or different from declarative clauses.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Clarifying comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative, but intonation may also be different between questions and declarative statements.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Clarifying comments: This feature deals with the presence or absence of a construction where the only difference between the interrogative and the declarative is marked by tone. Please note tone (not intonation) is the focus here which is a particle and bound to the constituent.

Feature: Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Clarifying comments: Ideophones are marked words that depict sensory imagery, e.g. 'glimmer', 'twiddle, 'tinkle'. In some languages, ideophones may have different morphosyntactic characteristics from other word classes (e.g. they have different morphology, or they have no morphology at all while other classes do; or they may be extremely free when it comes to word order, in comparison to other words). They may also feature sounds that are not present anywhere else in the language. Every language probably has ideophones, but not every language has a very well defined class of ideophones.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Clarifying comments: This feature concerns polar interrogative constructions where the main verb is repeated, once in the affirmative form and again in the negated form, as a pragmatically unmarked way of asking questions. The negated form can also occur before the affirmative form.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns negative words that function as auxiliary verbs, in that they inflect as verbs but occur only with other verbs. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.  A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite"/"connegative" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns negative words that do not inflect and are not bound to the verb. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analysed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking.  This question should be answered yes (1) if negation is marked by a phonologically independent, non-inflected word (particle), regardless of whether any other strategy can also be used to mark negation (e.g. a language that uses double marking of negation through both a particle AND a verbal affix would be coded as yes (1)).

Feature: Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns verb(s) of giving, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English went and go. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique

Feature: Is there an inclusory construction?
Clarifying comments: We are looking for a nonsingular referent which is expressed by a nonsingular form (superset), and a singular form (subset). The element expressing the superset could be either a free pronoun or a bound pronoun. In the example: 'We Harald talked' (_Harald and I talked._) the free 1PL. pronoun is the superset, and included within that is the subset which is the 1SG. pronoun and the proper noun 'Harald.' In some languages, this may be expressed by associative duals and plurals. This feature includes implicit inclusory constructions (as seen above) and explicit inclusory constructions which may have an overt inclusory marker in the construction to further mark the inclusory construction. It is worth noting the subset can compromise of various word classes such as proper nouns, numerals, demonstratives etc, and some languages also have inclusory conjunction forms.

Feature: Is there a phonologically free passive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Clarifying comments: Passivization is a valency reducing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives', 'anticausatives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking passive clauses.
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Clarifying comments: An antipassive marker detransitivizes verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique. In a construction with ergative alignment, this means that the A argument of a transitive clause is encoded as the S argument in a corresponding antipassive clause. An antipassive marker often also has other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, this feature targets any intransitivising marker that is not, or not only, a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets [phonologically independent](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) particles or auxiliaries marking antipassive clauses.
Function: antipassive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Clarifying comments: For languages with multiple passive constructions (e.g. 'personal' and 'impersonal' passives), this question should be answered 1 if the agent can be overtly expressed in any of these types of passive clauses. If the agent is overtly expressed, it may be unmarked or it may be marked in a number of ways: by case marking or adpositions, word order, etc.
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Reflexive markers indicate that a participant is coreferential with another participant in the clause or sentence (cf. Haspelmath & The APiCS Consortium 2013). Any [free](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) form that expresses reflexive meaning counts as a reflexive pronoun. A reflexive pronoun can also be derived from regular independent pronouns with reflexive morphology (e.g. *him-self* in English, *lui-même* in French). If reflexive meaning is expressed with a body part noun, e.g. 'body' or 'head' ('They are scolding their body' to mean 'They are scolding themselves'), this also counts as 1. One reflexive pronoun (e.g. only for a certain person) is enough for "1" here. Emphatic pronouns (e.g. 'She cooked it (by) herself.') do not trigger a "1", since they do not express a participant.

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Clarifying comments: Reciprocal pronouns are bipartite if they can be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers (e.g. each + other; two + two). So this question asks whether there are any [phonologically independent](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'Wordhood'-and-phonological-boundness-or-(in)dependence) reciprocal markers that cannot be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers. These markers may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. They need to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized.

Feature: Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Clarifying comments: This question aims at capturing productive marking of tense that makes distinctions into remoteness of time in relation to the point of reference or utterance. The actual marking can tonal, verbal affixation, suppletion or any other means of marking. Beware that it is important to tease out if the distinction is aspectual or modal rather than temporal. For example, "present perfect" is a kind of aspect that involves "current relevance", and may therefore more likely occur in recent time - but it can refer to events further in the past as well.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with bound marking on the verb root that denotes grammatical mood. This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and other possible worlds, or speaker's attitude) and aims to capture phonologically bound elements.  While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies phonologically independent possessive pronouns that are not formed by the application of regular possessive or core case marking to more general pronominal forms. Instead, languages that qualify for a 1 code for this feature form at least some possessive pronouns through some process other than the usual possessive marking, or, frequently, with suppletive forms. Note that special adnominal possessive pronouns are most commonly found in the 1st and 2nd person.  To qualify as 'special adnominal possessive pronouns', the possessive pronouns must not be identical to the pronominal forms used for core arguments. It is not necessary for the possessive pronouns to be dedicated solely to the function of possession, provided that the criteria above are satisfied.

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Can augmentative function (i.e. larger size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.

Feature: Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying comments: Can diminutive function (i.e. smaller size) be marked by a shift of noun class? We are looking for morphemes in the sentence which vary depending on the noun used, and that one of these morphemes can be used to change the meaning of a noun by adding the meaning 'small'. These morphemes should be a closed class of under about 30 (our definition of a gender system). This needs to be a productive pattern. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.

Feature: Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns regular marking of singular number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB042	Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB042) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB043	Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB043) which focusses on the bound marking of dual number.

Feature: Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns regular marking of plural number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB044 Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB044) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity (articles) or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns regular marking of trial number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB165	Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB165) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a phonologically free element?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns regular marking of paucal number in the noun phrase by a marker that is not bound to the noun, but free-standing. The marking should be on an open set of nouns, not a restricted set. This feature is in contrast to [GB166 Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB166)) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number. (For more on wordhood and bound marking, please see this [page](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/'on-the-verb-noun'-or-'by-morphology').  Number marking is often fused with other functions, such as definiteness/specificity or gender/noun class. It is possible for the number marker to also signal other functions and be coded as 1, as long as they don't interfere with the distinctions in numbers and as long as number marking is productive and regular.

Feature: Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Clarifying comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. This feature asks whether there is a large or open class of nouns whose gender/noun class assignment is not predictable based on phonology or semantics. In other words, such a class will appear to be assigned arbitrarily.

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's direct sensory evidence for some event or action. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential meaning, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning by the use of adverbs (e.g. "John apparently ate the cake") or lexical verbs in multi-clausal constructions (e.g. "I saw that John had eaten the cake"). Visual evidence is a common form of information encoded with a direct evidential, however direct evidentiality may also include auditory or other non-visual categories of sensory evidence. This question should be answered 'yes' (1) if the language has a single direct evidential or any number of sensory evidentials.

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Clarifying comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's indirect, non-sensory evidence for some event or action. Grammatical marking of evidentials involves the use of grammaticalized markers such as affixes or other morphology, evidential particles, or evidential auxiliary verbs to convey the evidential meaning, in contrast to constructions that create this meaning through the use of adverbs (e.g. "John reportedly ate the cake") or lexical verbs in multi-clause constructions (e.g. "They say that John ate the cake"). Indirect evidentiality usually involves inference from physical evidence or second-hand knowledge such as hearsay. This question should be answered yes (1) if there is a single category of indirect evidentiality or any number of inferential or reportative evidential categories marked grammatically.

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Clarifying comments: Interrogative verbs are verbs that include a semantic wh-element. In other words, the semantic content of interrogative verb roots includes an element equivalent to a content question, e.g., meaning 'to do what' or 'to be who'. The wh-element needs to behave like a verb in the language, e.g., if the language is English, it should take verbal morphology, appearing, e.g., as in 'you what-ed yesterday?' (to mean 'you did what yesterday?'). The feature does not include verbs of asking or interrogative forms created through affixation of interrogative markers to non-interrogative verb roots.

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Clarifying comments: For example, English contrasts 'how many' versus 'how much'.

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Clarifying comments: In situ means the normal position for a non-interrogative NP in the same participant role. This question is concerned with the use of in-situ content interrogative nominals as a general question construction. This question should be answered yes (1) if questions formed with in-situ interrogatives are pragmatically unmarked and are used commonly (e.g. not only in restrictive contexts such as echo questions or constructions with multiple interrogatives).

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Clarifying comments: Can (non-correlative) relative clauses immediately follow the noun they modify (e.g. '[The woman who has a green hat] is tall')? This question only concerns relative clauses that immediately follow the noun, without requiring an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause - which would make them correlative relative clauses (e.g. '[The woman who has a green hat] she is tall') (see [GB330](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB330)).

Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Clarifying comments: Can (non-correlative) relative clauses immediately precede the noun they modify (e.g. '[Who has a green hat the woman] is tall')? This question only concerns relative clauses that immediately precede the noun, without requiring an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause - which would make them correlative relative clauses (e.g. 'I saw her [who has a green hat the woman]') (see [GB330](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB330)).

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Clarifying comments: Is a relativized noun morphosyntactically part of the relative clause? This could mean different things in different languages. In some languages, for example, the relativized noun may literally be inside the relative clause, in terms of placement ('[A green hat the woman has] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'). In other languages, the noun may receive case marking for its function inside the relative clause rather than its function inside the main clause (e.g. 'man-SUBJ greeted [woman-SUBJ who has a green hat]' as opposed to 'man-SUBJ greeted [woman-OBJ who has a green hat]). Do not consider correlative relative clauses here (see [GB330](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB330)). It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever).

Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Clarifying comments: Are there relative clauses that require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause? For example, '[The woman who has a green hat] she is tall.'

Feature: Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Clarifying comments: Is there a (non-correlative) relative clause that is not adjacent to its modified noun? For example, in 'The woman is tall [who has a green hat]', the noun (woman) is not adjacent to its modifying relative clause (who has a green hat). It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). Do not consider correlative relative clauses for this feature (see [GB330](https://github.com/grambank/Grambank/wiki/GB330)).

Feature: Is there a decimal numeral system?
Clarifying comments: Are some multiples of 10 starting from 30 formed with a decimal base? e.g. 30 = 3x10, 40 = 4x10, etc. Or are expressions between these decimals (20-30, 30-40, etc.) formed as 20+1, 20+2, .., 20+9; 30+1, 30+2, .., 30+9? The coding should reflect the earliest attested (i.e. not merely inferred) stage so if a pre-borrowing stage is attested, this should be coded.

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Clarifying comments: Are some numerals above 5 formed with 5 as a base? For example, 6 = 5+1, 7 = 7+2, 8 = 5+3, 9 = 5+4, 11 = 5+5+1, etc.? One example of this is enough for a 1.

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Clarifying comments: Are some numerals for multiples of 20 expressed using a base-20 system? (e.g. 40 = 2x20; 60 = 3x20; 80 = 4x20; 120 = 6x20, etc.) Or are numerals in between these multiples of 20 formed as 20+1, 20+2, .., 20+19; 40+1, 40+2, .., 40+19, etc.?

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Clarifying comments: Body part tallying systems are counting systems that use body parts other than hands, feet, fingers or toes. Counting starts from one hand, tallying parts of the body along the arm, up to the head and then continuing with symmetric tally points down the other side of the body. Body tallying systems are usually only be used in some social situations, such as traditional bride price negotiations. If the words for head or body mean 10/20, or eye means 1, and the system could be interpreted as decimal or vigesimal, this does not indicate a body part tallying system.

Feature: Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns languages with obligatory indexing of the person of the argument somewhere in the clause (i.e. either on the verb or by clitics). The question asks whether the markers are deleted under certain circumstances. In order for there to be neutralization, there needs to be something to "neutralize" to begin with, i.e. languages without marking of person anywhere in the clause should be coded "0" for this feature. For this question do not consider independent pronouns.
Function: person, valency change, TAM, passive, antipassive, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments

Feature: Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Clarifying comments: This quote from [Kulikov and Lavidas (2008)](http://www.fabula.org/actualites/typology-of-labile-verbs-focus-on-diachrony_27119.php) serves as a very good clarification. For this question we are only interested in P-labile verbs, not A-labile verbs.  _The term ‘labileʼ refers to verbs or verbal forms which can show valency alternation, i.e. changes in syntactic pattern, with no formal change in the verb. Very often (but not always) the term ‘labileʼ is only employed to refer to verbs (or verbal forms) which can be employed both transitively and intransitively, as in (1-2); some scholars use other, less widely accepted terms in this sense, such as ‘ambitransitiveʼ (R. M. W. Dixon 1994) or ‘optionally transitive' (J. G. Miller 1993):_  (1) English ``` a. John broke the vase. b. The vase broke. ```` (2) Greek ``` a. O         Janis      efage   mesimeriano. the:NOM   Janis:NOM  ate:3SG lunch:ACC 'Janis ate lunch.'  b. O        Janis      efage. the:NOM  Janis:NOM  ate:3SG 'Janis ate.' ```  (1) exemplifies patient-preserving lability (P-lability), while (2) illustrates an agent-preserving lability (A-lability), which is not relevant for this question.

Feature: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns verb(s) of seeing/watching/looking, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.  Please note that we are not interested in words that are translated to "look for", "seek" etc. This feature is concerned with the transitive verb of the acting fo seeing, not metaphorical extensions such as "seek up".
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique

Feature: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Clarifying comments: This question concerns verb(s) of coming, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique

Feature: Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments: Do S, A, and P arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. only nouns or only pronouns, or a particular tense or person) shows accusative alignment.  Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.  Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includes what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).  Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments: Do S, P, and A arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows ergative alignment.  Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.  Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).  Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Clarifying comments: Are S, A, and P arguments flagged identically? In case of split systems, reply with "1" if any of the subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows neutral alignment. Reply with "1" if none of the three arguments is overtly flagged (i.e. if all three arguments are zero-marked).  Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.  Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).  Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Clarifying comments: This feature asks whether there are different 2nd person pronoun forms that are used based on the level of respect accorded by the speaker to the addressee. In some cases polite pronouns are used to indicate a level of formality or unfamiliarity between speaker and addressee. In other cases politeness distinctions are used according to very specific social relationships between speaker and addressee, such as relative age, social status, or kinship. If multiple 2nd person pronoun forms exist in a single number category, and their use is patterned according to the level of intimacy or hierarchy of social relationship between speaker and addressee, this will suffice for a (1) code.

Feature: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying comments: In verbs of thinking and knowing, is there a complementizer preposed to the complement? This is for example the case in English. The complementiser in the sentence "I knew that Ashley was a genius" is _that_ and it is preposed to the complement clause ("Ashley was a genius"). The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free, the position in relation to the complement clause is what is relevant.

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying comments: In verbs of thinking and knowing, is there a complementizer postposed to the complement? In English, the complementiser in the sentence "I knew that Ashley was a genius" is _that_ and it is preposed to the complement clause ("Ashley was a genius"). In Japanese however, the complementiser (_to_) is postposed (i.e. "I knew Ashley was a genius _that_"). The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free, the position in relation to the complement clause is what is relevant.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a prefix or proclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive prefix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of prefixes or proclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a prefix or proclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the morpheme that marks possession indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to that possessed noun.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a suffix or enclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive suffix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of suffixes or enclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that follows and is phonologically bound to the possessor noun/pronoun.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a suffix or enclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the possessive suffix indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by a phonologically bound element that follows and is phonologically dependent on the possessed noun.

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and "reality" and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.  While negation or interrogation can be considered as grammatical moods, they are not included in this feature.

Feature: Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such).  These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.  A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modify main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying comments: This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do no inflect (i.e. do not change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. This means that words such as "tomorrow" and "yesterday" do not qualify as productively marking future and hodiernal past. If there are any questions regarding this, please do bring it up with the group.  A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Clarifying comments: This feature identifies languages that do not require a phonologically overt S or A argument expressed by a noun phrase or independent pronoun when the referent can be inferred from context. These languages are often called 'pro-drop' languages, and the phenomenon is generally referred to as 'null anaphora' or 'zero anaphora'.  Here 'omitted' means phonologically unexpressed (we do not intend for this feature to make any distinctions regarding the theoretical status of a null anaphor). To count as (1), pro-drop should occur where the S or A argument might otherwise be expressed by an independent pronoun or full noun phrase. Specifically, pro-drop should occur in simple, declarative main clauses.  Pro-drop is not mutually exclusive with indexing of the S or A argument on the verb. If, in the absence of an independent pronoun or nominal S or A, there is indexing of this argument on the verb, you may still code 1.
